name: Ad Hominem
description: Attacking the person making the argument rather than addressing the argument itself.
logicalForm: Person A makes claim X. Person B attacks person A. Therefore, X is false.
example: You can't trust John's opinion on climate change because he's not a scientist.

name: Anecdotal Evidence
description: Using personal experiences or isolated examples instead of sound arguments or compelling evidence.
logicalForm: Personal experience A supports conclusion X. Therefore, X is true.
example: My grandfather smoked every day and lived until 97, so smoking can't be that bad for you.

name: Appeal to Authority
description: Using the opinion of an authority figure or institution as evidence when the authority is not relevant to the argument.
logicalForm: Authority A believes X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Einstein believed in God, so God must exist.

name: Appeal to Consequences
description: Arguing that a belief is true or false based on the consequences of accepting it.
logicalForm: If X is true, then Y will happen. Y is undesirable. Therefore, X is false.
example: If we allow same-sex marriage, traditional families will collapse. Therefore, same-sex marriage is wrong.

name: Appeal to Emotion
description: Manipulating emotions rather than using valid reasoning to support an argument.
logicalForm: Emotional appeal is made. Therefore, conclusion X is true.
example: If you don't support this policy, children will suffer.

name: Appeal to Ignorance
description: Claiming something is true because it has not been proven false, or vice versa.
logicalForm: It has not been proven that X is false. Therefore, X is true.
example: No one has proven that aliens don’t exist, so they must be real.

name: Appeal to Novelty
description: Arguing that something is better simply because it is new or modern.
logicalForm: X is new. Therefore, X is better than Y (which is old).
example: This new smartphone has the latest features, so it must be the best on the market.

name: Appeal to Tradition
description: Arguing that something is correct or better simply because it is older or traditional.
logicalForm: X is a tradition. Therefore, X is correct/right/better.
example: We’ve always done it this way, so it must be the best way.

name: Bandwagon
description: Arguing that something is true or right because many people believe it or do it.
logicalForm: Most people believe X. Therefore, X is true.
example: Everyone is buying this product, so it must be good.

name: Begging the Question
description: Using the conclusion of an argument as one of its premises.
logicalForm: A is true because B is true. B is true because A is true.
example: The Bible is true because it says so in the Bible.

name: Cherry Picking
description: Selecting only evidence that supports a particular position while ignoring evidence that contradicts it.
logicalForm: Evidence A supports conclusion X. Evidence B contradicts X. Therefore, only A is considered.
example: The new diet works because I lost weight in the first week, ignoring the fact that I gained it back later.

name: Composition Fallacy
description: Assuming that what is true for the parts is also true for the whole.
logicalForm: Part A has property X. Therefore, whole B (which contains part A) has property X.
example: Each player on the team is a great athlete, so the team must be great.

name: Division Fallacy
description: Assuming that what is true for the whole is also true for its parts.
logicalForm: Whole B has property X. Therefore, part A (which is part of B) has property X.
example: The team is great, so each player must be great.

name: False Analogy
description: Making a comparison between two things that are not sufficiently similar to warrant the conclusion.
logicalForm: A is like B. A has property X. Therefore, B has property X.
example: Employees are like nails; just as nails must be hit on the head to make them work, so must employees.

name: False Cause
description: Assuming causation based solely on temporal sequence or correlation.
logicalForm: A happened before B. Therefore, A caused B.
example: I wore my lucky socks and then we won the game. The socks must be why we won.

name: False Dilemma
description: Presenting only two options when more exist, forcing a choice between extremes.
logicalForm: Either X or Y. Not X. Therefore, Y.
example: You're either with us or against us.

name: Gambler's Fallacy
description: Believing that past random events affect the probabilities of future random events.
logicalForm: Event A has occurred multiple times. Therefore, event B (which is independent of A) is more likely to occur.
example: The roulette wheel has landed on red five times in a row, so black is due next.

name: Genetic Fallacy
description: Judging something as either good or bad based on its origin rather than its current meaning or context.
logicalForm: X comes from source Y. Source Y is bad/good. Therefore, X is bad/good.
example: You can't trust that study on climate change because it was funded by an oil company.

name: Hasty Generalization
description: Drawing a broad conclusion from a small or unrepresentative sample.
logicalForm: Sample S is taken from population P. Conclusion C is drawn about P based on S.
example: I met two rude people from that city, so everyone from there must be rude.

name: Middle Ground
description: Assuming the compromise between two extremes is always correct.
logicalForm: Position X and position Y are extremes. Therefore, the middle position Z must be true.
example: Flat-Earthers say the Earth is flat; scientists say it’s round. The truth must be a dome shape.

name: No True Scotsman
description: Dismissing counterexamples to a generalization by redefining the terms.
logicalForm: Group A has property X. Counterexample Y is presented. Therefore, Y is not a true member of group A.
example: No true Scotsman puts sugar in his porridge.

name: Red Herring
description: Introducing irrelevant information to divert attention from the main argument.
logicalForm: Argument A is presented. Topic B is introduced. Therefore, argument A is false/ignored.
example: We shouldn't worry about the environment when there are so many people unemployed.

name: Slippery Slope
description: Arguing that one event will inevitably lead to a chain of negative consequences without sufficient evidence.
logicalForm: If A happens, then B will happen. If B happens, then C will happen. Therefore, if A happens, C will happen.
example: If we allow students to redo this exam, next they'll want to redo every assignment, and eventually they'll expect to pass without doing any work.

name: Straw Man
description: Misrepresenting someone's argument to make it easier to attack.
logicalForm: Person A has position X. Person B presents position Y (a distorted version of X). Person B attacks position Y. Therefore, X is false.
example: Person A: 'We should have stricter gun control.' Person B: 'Why do you want to take away all guns from law-abiding citizens?'

name: Tu Quoque
description: Dismissing someone's argument by accusing them of hypocrisy without addressing the argument itself.
logicalForm: Person A makes claim X. Person B responds with accusation Y against person A. Therefore, X is false.
example: How can you argue against smoking when you used to smoke?
